Posts.Content: Since I was 18, I've been having tumors removed from my breasts.(59 now) Several were calcifications and were benign. It sounds like you have a good doctor. If he isn't sure what it is, then he needs to find out. I have to say that this is the most frightening thing that can happen to a person, but cancer is treatable. It could turn out to be nothing, but if it's cancer you can fight it. I also have dense breasts and a history of cancer in my family. The density of the breasts makes it harder to tell sometimes what the shadows are. Keep posting and tell me how it goes.
Posts.Title: 26 yr old with bad mammogram and ultrasound

Posts.Content: I was when it was just the needle biopsy, but it's probably still a good idea to take a friend along. Just waiting to see the doctor can be so tedious without company.I wish you the best on the results.
Posts.Title: Fine Needle Biopsy

Posts.Content: It is terrible when the doctor's office calls and leaves a message after something like this. This still could be something benign as I had many benign tumors through the years. Sometimes they couldn't tell by the pictures for sure, so they would draw fluid or remove the tumor to test it. I hope you know by now what you're facing, and I'll pray that you get good news. Judy
Posts.Title: A little worried and concerned.... Looking for info.

Posts.Content: I have had several of those. It is relatively painless. They put a thin needle into the area where the cyst is and they draw out fluid. Then they can test the fluid for cancer. I had some that they couldn't get fluid from, and those were taken out. Several of them were calcium deposits. They can be cancerous but I've had several of those and they were all benign.
Posts.Title: Fine Needle Biopsy

Posts.Content: It is terrible when the doctor's office calls and leaves a message after something like this. This still could be something benign as I had many benign tumors through the years. Sometimes they couldn't tell by the pictures for sure, so they would draw fluid or remove the tumor to test it. I hope you know by now what you're facing, and I'll pray that you get good news. Judy
Posts.Title: A little worried and concerned.... Looking for info.

Posts.Content: Hi. I'm Judy, and when I was 18 I began having tumors removed from my breasts. They would show up every few years. In my early 30's I had a hysterctomy, and I always said that was the best surgery I ever had. I felt better and my monthly cycles were done. I had all the children I wanted. I've now had a mastectomy on the right side and I'd like to get the other off too. My insurance considers it a preventative measure and thay won't pay for it. My oncologist wants me to do the BRCA testing, and I haven't been able to afford it so far. The way I have understood it is that it may not make me feel better, but I can plan better as to prevention of cancer recurrence. Plus, it would mostly be for my daughter so she and her doctors could be more vigilant if it runs in our family. The counselor also said that if it's in our family, her insurance will be more likely to pay for her preventative care if the time comes.
Posts.Title: BRCA1 and BRCA2 Mutations and Desicions - Newbie needing help...

Posts.Content: I've had several surgical biopsies through the years. They do that if they're sure whether they're benign or not. I really don't no about the spot where these calcifications are, but mine always turned out benign. I guess some places can be worse than others, but I think it more depends on the type of cancer should you have that. I have heard of a few cases where people had cancer in both breasts at the same time, but not very often. Just keep in mind that it certainly may not be cancer.
Posts.Title: Surgical biopsy???

Posts.Content: Raider--I'm so sorry for you and for your mother. I really don't have any good answers for your question. When my mother had bone cancer, I fixed her favorite foods and I would insist that she eat some of it. I had chemo and the doctors told me fruit and vegetables, peanut butter, foods with iron were all good in terms of diet.
Posts.Title: Hello, I need some advice on stage 4 cancer...

Posts.Content: Brenda, I have metaplastic, triple-negative breast cancer. I've had 33 treatments of chemo and 33 radiation treatments. I did eventually peel as I went through radiation. The doctor gave me a cream that helped and I used it 3 times a day.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Survivor!

Posts.Content: Kermica, I'm not sure what to tell you. I had a bi-lateral mastectomy, chemo, and radiation. One thing that is helpful is to have a notebook to write questions and concerns in. The doctors move very quickly sometimes, and questions you need answered aren't if they're not written down. Let me give you a couple of sites to go to where there is a lot of activity in terms of questions, answers on breast cancer. csn.cancer.org is good ; and beyondtheshock.com ; I think you can get a lot of information there from people who have gone through the same thing as your friend.
Posts.Title: Information needed

Posts.Content: Kermica, It is amazing the survivor stories that find of people who seemed to be in the worst case scenerio in terms of cancer. There is certainly hope and many people say is the cancer may not go away completely, but you can live many, many years with it. Some people on the sites I go to had Stage 4 cancer which is supposed to be the worst, and are alive and well to tell about 10, 15, 20 years later. Keep the positive, fighting spirit alive and go for it. judy
Posts.Title: Information needed

Posts.Content: You would think so! But my oncologist didn't make me an appointment until she had all the test results. She did say that you can't always see the cancer cells, so maybe that's why this wasn't detected. I wish the very best for your friend.
Posts.Title: 2nd breast cancer surgery

Posts.Content: I don't think a second opinion is ever a bad idea. I would and have done it before.
Posts.Title: Should I get a 2nd opinion and push for a biopsy?

Posts.Content: Yellowrose-- Everything you said in the first two sentences described how I felt when I was told. (Triple-negative, metaplastic breast cancer) You don't sound full of pity. I was full of fear and grief and I cried for several days. I don't know how old your kids are, but I'd be as honest as possible. Yes, this is a terrible disease but it is treatable. And the treatments they have now are totally doable. Most of us get to the point that we say we will do everything we need to to erradicate the cancer.
Posts.Title: breast clinic have told me my biopsy results will be coming back as cancer

Posts.Content: Yellowrose-- Everything you said in the first two sentences described how I felt when I was told. (Triple-negative, metaplastic breast cancer) You don't sound full of pity. I was full of fear and grief and I cried for several days. I don't know how old your kids are, but I'd be as honest as possible. Yes, this is a terrible disease but it is treatable. And the treatments they have now are totally doable. Most of us get to the point that we say we will do everything we need to to erradicate the cancer.
Posts.Title: breast clinic have told me my biopsy results will be coming back as cancer

Posts.Content: That sounds unusual. But thank goodness that the cancer is gone! My cancer was triple-negative and right now I have something in my other breast that they "say" is benign. I expect my left breast will be taken off too in the next few years. I did have to take chemo, but my doctor said that the negative breast cancers are harder to treat, so maybe having the her2 positive will make it easier to treat. I am now sending all the positive thoughts I can gather your way!
Posts.Title: question from breast cancer patient
